<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 277, 228, 292]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 301, 339, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Probability & Statistics 2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 384, 392, 399]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 880, 636]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 665, 211, 678]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 681, 728, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
It is known that \(1\%\) of houses in a certain area have a wind turbine. A random sample of 400 houses in this area is chosen for a survey on domestic heating. The number of houses in the sample that have a wind turbine is denoted by \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 134, 581, 151]]<|/det|>
Use a suitable approximating distribution to find \(\mathrm{P}(X \leqslant 3)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 134, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 81, 92, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 78, 918, 117]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(X\) has the distribution \(\mathsf{B}\left(8, \frac{3}{4}\right)\). A random sample of 100 values of \(X\) is chosen, and the sample mean, \(\overline{X}\), is found.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 129, 146, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 128, 700, 147]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(\overline{X} > 6.2)\) . You are **not** expected to use a continuity correction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 128, 920, 147]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 158, 917, 755]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 765, 146, 784]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 765, 770, 784]]<|/det|>
State why the Central Limit Theorem was needed in the calculation in part **(a)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 765, 920, 784]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 918, 120]]<|/det|>
The time, \(T\) minutes, for a certain daily bus journey is normally distributed. The bus company claims that the mean of \(T\) is 45. A passenger believes that the mean of \(T\) is actually greater than 45. She notes the times taken for this journey on a random sample of 60 days. The results are summarised below.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 131, 687, 151]]<|/det|>
\[n = 60\qquad \Sigma t = 2750\qquad \Sigma t^2 = 127000\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 164, 146, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 164, 675, 182]]<|/det|>
Calculate unbiased estimates of the population mean and variance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 164, 918, 182]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 917, 460]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 475, 148, 492]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 475, 588, 492]]<|/det|>
Test the passenger's belief at the \(5\%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 475, 918, 492]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
At an entertainment centre, the cost for using a particular video game is \$0.40 per minute. The number of minutes for which people use the video game has mean 15 and variance 9.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 777, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the mean and variance of the amount people pay for using the video game.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 151, 917, 510]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 520, 551, 539]]<|/det|>
Each day, 35 people independently use the video game.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 552, 148, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 552, 672, 570]]<|/det|>
Find the mean and variance of the total amount paid by 35 people.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 552, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 90]]<|/det|>
The random variables \(W\) and \(X\) have the independent distributions \(\text{Po}(1.2)\) and \(\text{Po}(2.3)\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 104, 180, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 104, 384, 122]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(3 \leqslant W + X \leqslant 5)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 134, 917, 308]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 319, 915, 337]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(S\) is the sum of 100 independent values of \(W\) and 200 independent values of \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 350, 180, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 350, 580, 369]]<|/det|>
Use a suitable approximation to find \(\mathrm{P}(S > 600)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 350, 920, 369]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 381, 917, 925]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 660, 91]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(Y\) has the distribution \(\mathrm{Po}(\lambda)\), where \(\lambda > 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 100, 551, 125]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\frac{5}{2}\mathrm{P}(Y = 3) + \mathrm{P}(Y = 4) = \mathrm{P}(Y = 5).\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 135, 312, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\lambda\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 918, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 163, 917, 952]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 72, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
A manufacturer of cell phones claims that \(25\%\) of students own a Pumpkin phone. Jeyeraj thinks that the proportion of students at his large college who own a Pumpkin phone is less than \(25\%\) . He plans to test the manufacturer's claim. He chooses a random sample of 30 students at his college. If the number of students who own a Pumpkin phone is less than 5, Jeyeraj will reject the manufacturer's claim.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 146, 167]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 149, 447, 167]]<|/det|>
State suitable hypotheses for the test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 149, 918, 167]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 148, 352]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 918, 368]]<|/det|>
Given that the true proportion of students at the college who own a Pumpkin phone is \(10\%\) , use a binomial distribution to find the probability of a Type II error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 350, 918, 368]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 900, 88]]<|/det|>
At Florence's college, in a random sample of 40 students, it was found that 5 own a Pumpkin phone.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 144, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 103, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
Calculate an approximate \(95\%\) confidence interval for the proportion of students at Florence's college who own a Pumpkin phone. [3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 148, 917, 952]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 70, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 70, 628, 90]]<|/det|>
\(X\) is a random variable with probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 104, 650, 144]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \begin{cases} (1 + \cos \pi x) & 0\leqslant x\leqslant 1,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}. \end{cases}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 163, 148, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 160, 400, 185]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathrm{P}\Big(X < \frac{1}{2}\Big) = \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{\pi}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 163, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 191, 917, 952]]<|/det|>
